entry.title: üéì [Deep Dive] About Custom Hook
entry.content:
üìò What is Custom Hook?

A Custom Hook in React is a reusable function that starts with the prefix use and leverages one or more built-in React Hooks (like useState, useEffect, etc.) to encapsulate and share stateful logic between components, without dealing with any UI rendering.

‚ö†Ô∏è Key characteristics:

  • Must start with use (e.g., useFetch, useForm, useTimer)
  • Can call other Hooks inside
  • Returns values or functions (not JSX)
  • Encourages logic reuse and separation of concerns

‚ùì Why we need to use Custom Hook?

Custom Hooks are used to encapsulate reusable logic in React. Instead of copying and pasting the same useEffect, useState, or fetch code across multiple components, you write it once as a function ‚Äî a Custom Hook ‚Äî and reuse it everywhere.

‚úÖ Benefits of Custom Hooks:

  • Avoid code duplication: You don‚Äôt have to repeat the same logic in multiple components.

  • Improve readability: Your components focus only on rendering UI, not logic.

  • Encourage separation of concerns: Logic lives in hooks, UI lives in components.

  • Easier to test: You can test the logic of your hook without involving the UI.

  • Composable: You can even combine multiple hooks into one complex behavior.

üìò Example: Why Custom Hooks Are Helpful

Instead of writing this in every component:

useEffect(() => {
  setLoading(true);
  fetch('/api/data')
    .then(res => res.json())
    .then(setData)
    .catch(setError)
    .finally(() => setLoading(false));
}, []);

You can extract it into a reusable hook:

// useFetch.js
import { useState, useEffect } from 'react';

export function useFetch(url) {
  const [data, setData] = useState(null);
  const [loading, setLoading] = useState(true);
  const [error, setError] = useState(null);

  useEffect(() => {
    setLoading(true);
    fetch(url)
      .then(res => res.json())
      .then(setData)
      .catch(setError)
      .finally(() => setLoading(false));
  }, [url]);

  return { data, loading, error };
}

Then in any component:

import { useFetch } from '../hooks/useFetch';

function MyComponent() {
  const { data, loading, error } = useFetch('/api/data');

  if (loading) return <p>Loading...</p>;
  if (error) return <p>Error occurred</p>;

  return <div>{data.name}</div>;
}

entry.title: üéì [Deep Dive] About Redux
entry.content:
üìù About Redux

Understand What It Is, Why It Matters, and How It Works

‚úÖ Introduction

Redux provides a centralized store to hold all application state.
Instead of each component managing its own local state and passing data via props,
Redux allows components to read and update shared global state in a consistent and scalable way.

üëâ For example, the shopping cart in an e-commerce website is typically managed with Redux, since it needs to be accessible and modifiable from multiple pages like the product list, cart page, and checkout.

üîÅ Core Concepts

Redux has three main building blocks:

Concept Description
Store Holds the application‚Äôs state (like a central database in memory)
Action A plain JavaScript object that describes what happened
Reducer A pure function that determines how state changes in response to an action

‚úÖ Why Use Redux?

Redux offers a number of benefits, especially for medium to large-scale applications:

  • ‚úÖ Centralized state management ‚Äî all application state is stored in a single place, making it easier to access and manage.
  • ‚úÖ Avoid deeply nested props passing (a.k.a. ‚Äúprop drilling‚Äù) ‚Äî no need to pass data through multiple layers of components.
  • ‚úÖ Share state across distant components ‚Äî such as sharing cart data between the navbar and the checkout page.
  • ‚úÖ Debuggable via Redux DevTools ‚Äî track every state change over time and replay actions for debugging.
  • ‚úÖ Separate state logic from UI logic ‚Äî improves code clarity and reusability.
  • ‚úÖ Easy to reason about ‚Äî the strict unidirectional data flow makes the application behavior more understandable.

üõ†Ô∏è Redux Workflow in React

Here‚Äôs a typical step-by-step workflow for using Redux in a React application:

  1. Create a Redux store
    Use configureStore() from Redux Toolkit to initialize the global store that will hold your entire app‚Äôs state.

  2. Create a slice (module of state)
    Use createSlice() to define:
    • the initial state
    • reducer functions (how state changes)
    • automatically generated action creators

  3. Provide the store to your app
    Wrap your React app with <Provider store={store}> so all components can access the Redux store.

  4. Dispatch actions from components
    Use useDispatch() to trigger an action, like dispatch(addToCart(product)).

  5. Reducers handle actions and update the state
    Redux automatically calls the corresponding reducer function, which returns a new state.

  6. Components read updated state
    Use useSelector() to read specific slices of state (e.g., state.cart.items). When state changes, components re-render automatically.

  7. (Optional) Use middleware for async logic
    Use redux-thunk or redux-saga if you need to handle side effects like API calls.

üõí For Example: Managing a Shopping Cart

In an e-commerce application, the shopping cart is a perfect use case for Redux:

  • üß© Multiple pages (Product List, Cart Page, Checkout Page) all need access to the cart
  • üîÑ You want to update cart state from any page
  • üöÄ You want cart data to persist as users navigate

Redux lets you:

  • üóÇÔ∏è Store cart items in a centralized state (store.cart.items)
  • ‚ûï Add to cart using dispatch(addToCart(product))
  • ‚ùå Remove or clear cart with dedicated actions like dispatch(removeFromCart(id))
  • üëÄ Access cart data anywhere using useSelector((state) => state.cart.items)

üéØ With Redux, your shopping cart logic becomes cleaner, centralized, and decoupled from individual components ‚Äî making your application easier to scale and maintain.

entry.title: üéì [Deep Dive] Practical useEffect Use Cases
entry.content:
üéØ Why This Matters

In the previous post, we introduced the basic concepts behind useEffect. Now, let‚Äôs dive into practical examples to understand why we need it ‚Äî and what issues can arise if we ignore it.

üìå Use Case 1: Fetching API Data

‚ùå Without useEffect (Wrong)

function BadComponent() {
  const [data, setData] = useState(null);

  fetch('https://api.example.com/data')
    .then(res => res.json())
    .then(data => setData(data));

  return <div>{JSON.stringify(data)}</div>;
}

  • Every render triggers a fetch

  • setData() causes re-render ‚Üí infinite loop

  • App becomes slow, unstable, or crashes

‚úÖ With useEffect (Correct)

function GoodComponent() {
  const [data, setData] = useState(null);

  useEffect(() => {
    fetch('https://api.example.com/data')
      .then(res => res.json())
      .then(data => setData(data));
  }, []);

  return <div>{JSON.stringify(data)}</div>;
}
  • fetch runs only once on mount
  • No repeated API calls

üìå Use Case 2: Setting up Event Listeners

‚ùå Without useEffect (Wrong)

function BadResizeComponent() {
  window.addEventListener('resize', () => {
    console.log(window.innerWidth);
  });

  return <div>Resize the window!</div>;
}
  • A new event listener is added on every render
  • Leads to memory leak and performance drop

‚úÖ With useEffect (Correct)

function GoodResizeComponent() {
  useEffect(() => {
    const handleResize = () => {
      console.log(window.innerWidth);
    };

    window.addEventListener('resize', handleResize);

    return () => window.removeEventListener('resize', handleResize);
  }, []);

  return <div>Resize the window!</div>;
}
  • Listener added once
  • Listener cleaned up properly when component unmounts

üìå Use Case 3: Timers (setInterval / setTimeout)

‚ùå Without useEffect (Wrong)

function BadTimerComponent() {
  setInterval(() => {
    console.log('Tick');
  }, 1000);

  return <div>Timer running...</div>;
}
  • Every render creates a new interval
  • Leads to multiple timers ticking at once

‚úÖ With useEffect (Correct)

function GoodTimerComponent() {
  useEffect(() => {
    const timer = setInterval(() => {
      console.log('Tick');
    }, 1000);

    return () => clearInterval(timer); // cleanup
  }, []);

  return <div>Timer running...</div>;
}
  • Only one interval
  • Cleared on unmount

üß™ Understanding useEffect Comparison and Triggering

üíº How Dependency Comparison Works?

React‚Äôs useEffect hook uses shallow comparison for its dependency array:

üßê Primitive Values (number, string, boolean)

useEffect(() => {
  // Runs when userId changes
}, [userId]); // Compares with `===`
  • Uses strict equality (===) comparison
  • Effect runs only when the value actually changes

ü§î When useEffect Triggers?

  • First Render (Mount)
  • Always runs after initial render

üí° Subsequent Renders

  • Runs after render completes

-Only if shallow comparison detects changes in dependencies

‚≠ïÔ∏è The Render Cycle

  • Component renders (due to state/props change)

  • React compares each dependency with previous values

  • Effect executes if any dependency changed

üîë Key Points

  • useEffect runs asynchronously after render completes

  • Parent re-renders will cause child effects to re-evaluate

  • State updates (useState) trigger re-renders which may trigger effects

entry.title: üéì [Deep Dive] About useEffect
entry.content:
üìù Why Do We Need useEffect in React?

Understand What It Is, Why It Matters, and How It Works

‚úÖ Introduction

React‚Äôs function components are clean and powerful, but they come with a twist ‚Äî no lifecycle methods like componentDidMount. So how do we fetch data, set up timers, or listen to events?

That‚Äôs where useEffect comes in.

üîç What is useEffect?

useEffect is a React Hook that lets you perform side effects in function components.

üíª Common side effects include:

  • Fetching data from APIs
  • Setting up subscriptions or timers
  • Listening to window resize or scroll events
  • Manually updating the DOM

üõ†Ô∏è Basic Syntax

useEffect(() => {
  // your side effect logic here
}, [dependencies]);

üìà Example:

import React, { useState, useEffect } from 'react';

function ExampleComponent() {
  const [count, setCount] = useState(0);

  useEffect(() => {
    console.log('Count changed:', count);
  }, [count]); // runs when `count` changes

  return (
    <div>
      <button onClick={() => setCount(count + 1)}>
        Add +1
      </button>
    </div>
  );
}

üîÅ Three types of the dependency array

  • [] ‚Üí run once (on mount)
  • [count] ‚Üí run when count changes
  • no array ‚Üí run on every render

üí• What happens if you don‚Äôt use useEffect?

‚ùå Fetching data directly inside the component body

function BadComponent() {
  const [data, setData] = useState(null);

  // ‚ùå This will run every render ‚Äî bad!
  fetch('https://api.example.com/data')
    .then(res => res.json())
    .then(data => setData(data));

  return <div>{JSON.stringify(data)}</div>;
}

üö® What goes wrong?

  • fetch() runs ‚Üí setData() updates state

  • State update ‚Üí triggers re-render

  • Re-render the whole component and it will run fetch() again ‚Üí another state update‚Ä¶

  • üîÅ Infinite loop of requests ‚Üí bad for performance and may crash the app-

‚úÖ Fetching data with useEffect

function GoodComponent() {
  const [data, setData] = useState(null);

  useEffect(() => {
    fetch('https://api.example.com/data')
  }, []); 


  return (
      return <div>{JSON.stringify(data)}</div>;
  );
}
  • In this case, we use 
    useEffect(() => {
  fetch('https://api.example.com/data')
}, []);
    • Only runs once when the component mounts (first render)
    • Never re-runs, even if state/props change
    • So we avoid the Infinite loop of requests like above code

‚ùì Q&A: Common Questions About useEffect

1. What is the purpose of the cleanup function in useEffect?

In useEffect, you can return a function ‚Äî called the cleanup function ‚Äî that React will call when the component unmounts or before re-running the effect due to dependency changes.

The purpose of cleanup is to remove or cancel any ongoing side effects that should no longer be active, such as:

  • Removing event listeners
  • Clearing timers (setInterval or setTimeout)
  • Unsubscribing from subscriptions
  • Closing WebSocket connections

Without proper cleanup, you risk memory leaks, unexpected behaviors, and performance issues.

useEffect(() => {
  function handleResize() {
    console.log('Window resized:', window.innerWidth);
  }

  window.addEventListener('resize', handleResize);

  return () => {
    window.removeEventListener('resize', handleResize);
  };
}, []);

2. Can you have multiple useEffect hooks in the same component?

‚úÖ Yes, absolutely!

You can (and often should) use multiple useEffect hooks within a single component. Each useEffect should ideally manage one specific side effect.

This makes your code cleaner, easier to read, and easier to maintain.

Example:

useEffect(() => {
  console.log('Effect for count');
}, [count]);

useEffect(() => {
  console.log('Effect for name');
}, [name]);

Each effect operates independently, depending on its specific dependencies.

3. If there are multiple useEffect, what is their execution order?

React runs multiple useEffect hooks in the order they appear in your code ‚Äî top to bottom.

Even if different effects depend on different variables, the order is determined by their position in the component.

Example:

useEffect(() => {
  console.log('First Effect');
}, []);

useEffect(() => {
  console.log('Second Effect');
}, []);

useEffect(() => {
  console.log('Third Effect');
}, []);

Output after first render:

First Effect
Second Effect
Third Effect

Cleanup functions, if any, are called in reverse order before running the new effects.

entry.content:
You‚Äôll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

To add new posts, simply add a file in the _posts directory that follows the convention YYYY-MM-DD-name-of-post.ext and includes the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.
